verses.text: The words of King Lemuel, the oracle which his mother taught him:
verses.comment: This introductory verse tells us that the guidance which follows is divinely inspired and passed through parental instruction, exemplifying the value of tradition and wisdom handed down through generations.

verses.text: What are you doing, my son? What, son of my womb? What, son of my vows?
verses.comment: Lemuel's mother appeals to him lovingly, emphasizing a special relationship through birth and spiritual promises. The tradition of vows connects to Old Testament figures whose mothers dedicated them to God, hinting at the sanctity of life consecrated to the Lord.

verses.text: Do not give your strength to women, nor your ways to those who destroy kings.
verses.comment: A warning against moral and spiritual compromise, especially through illicit relationships that led many kings astray. The advice calls for integrity in leadership and hints at the broader theme of holiness and self-control.

verses.text: It is not for kings, Lemuel—it is not for kings to drink wine, nor for rulers to crave strong drink;
verses.comment: Sobriety is especially required of leaders, showing a need for clear judgment. Echoes priestly regulations and sets rulers apart for holy service, subtly signifying the dignity and responsibility of those set apart.

verses.text: Lest they drink and forget what is decreed, and pervert the rights of all the afflicted.
verses.comment: Wine can impair judgment, leading to injustice for those who are vulnerable. The text connects righteous leadership to the defense of the poor, a repeated biblical theme found in both Testaments.

verses.text: Give strong drink to those who are perishing, and wine to those who are bitter in soul;
verses.comment: This proverb uses irony to show that strong drink is for the desperate, not for those tasked with leadership. Wine, a symbol in scripture not only of joy but also sacrifice, is reserved for different occasions in sacred tradition.

verses.text: Let them drink and forget their poverty, and remember their misery no more.
verses.comment: Alcohol here is depicted as temporary comfort for the suffering. This underscores a contrast between worldly consolation and true peace, found ultimately in spiritual fulfillment.

verses.text: Open your mouth for the mute, for the rights of all who are destitute.
verses.comment: A direct call to advocate for the voiceless and needy. Caring for the poor echoes the command to love neighbor, seen in both Old and New Testament ethical teachings.

verses.text: Open your mouth, judge righteously, defend the rights of the poor and needy.
verses.comment: Justice and compassion are inseparable for leaders and for all believers. Acts of mercy are considered spiritual sacrifices, pleasing to God.

verses.text: Who can find a wife of noble character? Her value is far above rubies.
verses.comment: This begins the acrostic poem praising the virtuous woman, sometimes interpreted allegorically as the people of God, the Church, and even typologically as a figure of Christ's own bride.

verses.text: The heart of her husband trusts in her, and he will have no lack of gain.
verses.comment: The bond of trust within marriage mirrors the covenant relationship between God and His people—marked by faithfulness and abundance.

verses.text: She does him good, and not harm, all the days of her life.
verses.comment: The wife's constant dedication reflects the enduring love and goodness God has for His people.

verses.text: She seeks wool and flax, and works with willing hands.
verses.comment: Her diligence illustrates stewardship of resources—a trait praised throughout Scripture. This is also a spiritual image of fruitful labor.

verses.text: She is like merchant ships, bringing food from afar.
verses.comment: The woman provides abundantly, a metaphor for spiritual nourishment given by God's wisdom.

verses.text: She rises while it is still night and gives food to her household and portions to her servant girls.
verses.comment: Faithful to her vocation, the virtuous woman's care extends to all in her household. This resonates with themes of stewardship and the dignity of work.

verses.text: She considers a field and buys it; out of her earnings she plants a vineyard.
verses.comment: Her wise investment and fruitfulness reflect the biblical theme of working with creation. The vineyard is a strong image of spiritual fruitfulness in the New Testament.

verses.text: She girds herself with strength and makes her arms strong.
verses.comment: Strength is both physical and spiritual, alluding to grace received through faithfulness and perseverance.

verses.text: She perceives that her merchandise is profitable; her lamp does not go out at night.
verses.comment: The continual burning lamp recalls the parable of the ten virgins, calling believers to vigilance and readiness for the coming of the Bridegroom.

verses.text: She puts her hands to the distaff, and her fingers hold the spindle.
verses.comment: Her diligent labor ties to the creation mandate: to work and steward the earth. Hands-on work is elevated to an act of faith.

verses.text: She opens her hand to the poor and reaches out her hands to the needy.
verses.comment: Generosity towards the poor echoes a core message of Christ, who identifies himself with the needy.

verses.text: She has no fear for her household when it snows, for everyone is clothed in scarlet.
verses.comment: Scarlet clothing signifies care and dignity. Such preparation recalls spiritual clothing, a metaphor for being clothed in righteousness.

verses.text: She makes coverings for her bed; her clothing is fine linen and purple.
verses.comment: Fine linen and purple are signs of kingship and dignity, typologically linked to the royal garments given to Christ.

verses.text: Her husband is respected at the city gates, where he sits among the elders of the land.
verses.comment: Family honor extends to community influence, portraying the fruitful results of virtuous living.

verses.text: She makes linen garments and sells them; she supplies sashes to the merchants.
verses.comment: Her work benefits not only her own household but others, showing how virtue overflows to bless the wider community.

verses.text: Strength and dignity are her clothing, and she laughs at the days to come.
verses.comment: Her confidence comes from her relationship to God. To be clothed in 'strength and dignity' signifies being prepared spiritually as well as practically.

verses.text: She opens her mouth with wisdom, and the teaching of kindness is on her tongue.
verses.comment: Her words manifest wisdom and mercy, pointing to the spiritual gift of teaching handed down within the community of faith.

verses.text: She watches over the ways of her household and does not eat the bread of idleness.
verses.comment: Vigilance and diligence in the home reflect spiritual watchfulness, a repeated admonition in scripture.

verses.text: Her children rise up and call her blessed; her husband also praises her:
verses.comment: The poetic praise echoes Mary being called 'blessed among women,' connecting to honor given to holy women throughout salvation history.

verses.text: Many women have done excellently, but you surpass them all.
verses.comment: The surpassing excellence of the virtuous woman parallels the exaltation of the chosen bride in other biblical allegories.

verses.text: Charm is deceptive, and beauty is fleeting; but a woman who fears the LORD is to be praised.
verses.comment: True worth is found in reverence for God, not mere outward appearance. This emphasizes inner transformation over superficial qualities.

verses.text: Give her the fruit of her hands, and let her works praise her in the gates.
verses.comment: Praise is not just for the individual, but for the fruits borne through a life of virtue. The public recognition parallels the commendation of saints and the lasting legacy of those who live righteously.
